statement:
If $G$ is transitive on the set $A$, then $G$ is primitive on $A$ if and
only if for each $a\in A$, $G_a$ is a maximal subgroup of $G$. Here
$G_a=\operatorname{Stab}_G(a)$ is the stabilizer of $a\in A$.

First claim that if $G$ is transitive on $A$ and $B\subset A$ is a with
$a\in B$, then $G_B=\{\sigma\in G\ \mid\ \sigma(B)=B\}$ is a subgroup of
$G$ containing $G_a$. It is obvious that $G_B$ is a subgroup, since
$$\begin{gathered}
\sigma\in G_B\Rightarrow \sigma(B)=B\Rightarrow \sigma^{-1}(\sigma(B))=\sigma^{-1}(B)\Rightarrow B=\sigma^{-1}(B)\Rightarrow \sigma^{-1}\in G_B\\
\sigma,\tau\in G_B \Rightarrow (\sigma\tau)(B)=\sigma(\tau(B))=\sigma(B)=B\Rightarrow \sigma\tau\in G_B\end{gathered}$$
But also, if $\sigma\in G_a$ for $a\in B$, then $\sigma(a)=a$, so
$\sigma(B)\cap B\neq \emptyset$ and thus $\sigma(B)=B$ since $B$ is a
block system and thus $\sigma\in G_B$. This proves the claim.

To prove the theorem, note that for each $a\in A$, there is by the claim
a $1-1$ correspondence between containing $a$ and subgroups of $G$
containing $G_a$. Thus, $G$ is primitive on $A$ if and only if all
blocks are either of size $1$ or equal to $A$, if and only if any group
containing $G_a$ is either $G_a$ itself or $G$, if and only if for all
$a\in A$, $G_a$ is maximal in $G$.
names: transitive actions are primitive if and only if stabilizers are maximal subgroups
